author: Elmo Weeks
title: Savannah City Amateur set to tee off Saturday at restored Bacon Park
text:
Photos Back | Next Carl Elmore/For the Savannah Morning News
John Skeadas II attempts a birdie during the 2014 Savannah City Amateur. He defends his title at the event this weekend.
Back | Next Courtesy Bacon Park Golf Course
The trophy for the winner of the annual Savannah City Amateur golf tournament, which is Saturday and Sunday at Bacon Park Golf Course.
By Elmo Weeks
A new chapter in the history of the Savannah City Amateur will begin Saturday on an old course made new again.
The City Am will be played this weekend for the first time on the fully restored Donald Ross Course at Bacon Park Golf Course. During the past two years, the course has been redesigned under the management of OC Welch Golf Properties according to the original designs sketched by legendary golf architect Donald Ross.
The first nine holes were completed in 2014 and the City Am was contested on the restored first nine and the unrestored second nine. The second nine holes were completed earlier this fall but open for the first time today to allow registered City Am participants to play practice rounds.
The fully restored Ross Course will be open to the public for the first time on Sunday beginning at 3 p.m.
As of Thursday, there were nearly 100 players registered to play in the City Am, including defending champion John Skeadas II, and former champions Danny Nelson and Peter Brennan. The tournament’s honorary starter on Saturday will be Mike Stroud, who played his first City Am in 1969 and will strike the first shot at 7:45 a.m. on the first tee in honor of the late Marion “Big Daddy” Lowe, a legendary figure at Bacon Park who organized the Lowe Blitze in the mid-1970s for the area’s best players.
“From what I’ve seen, (OC Welch Golf Properties) has done a magnificent job of recreating the Ross Course,” said Skeadas, whose won this third City Am title in 2014. “The restoration of the original layout will make the golf course more difficult, and the second nine will now be as tough as the first nine. I think it’s reasonable to say that this year is the most important City Am in the past 35 years, and now that the golf course is finished, (the tournament) is going to gain momentum and be even better in future years.”
The second nine features some of the most difficult holes on the course, including Nos. 12, 13, 15 and 17. The 15th hole, a 418-yard par-4, and the 17th hole, a 233-yard par-3, are expected to be the most difficult holes on the reconfigured course.
“This is the first time the golf course will be like it’s supposed to be, and that’s a big deal,” said OC Welch Golf Properties president OC Welch, whose experiences working and playing golf at Bacon Park fueled his passion to restore the original Donald Ross layout. “We’ve gone above and beyond on the second nine, and (the City Am) is going to get to where it was supposed to be as a prestigious tournament instead of just another event on the calendar. We’ve done everything we wanted to do, and we’ve knocked it out of the park on this project, for sure.”
Although the course has not been opened for play, several players have toured the second nine during the past week in preparation for the tournament. The course’s total yardage will measure only 6,300 yards, but elevation changes, doglegs and speedy greens should protect against low scores.
“I can’t say if the course will be harder or easier, but we’ll all be in the same boat,” said Nelson, who was won multiple City Am titles since moving to Savannah in 1985. “The better conditions will certainly make it easier than it has been in the past, but there are a lot of nuances out there we haven’t seen before. I just think it’s a wonderful 18 holes of golf, and I think the (City of Savannah) should send a thank you card to OC Welch.”
